results.title: The Shackles You Cannot See
results.creator_credit: Robyn Fairbairn and St Mary's Anglican Girls' College
results.brief_description: Special Mention in the Senior Live Action category. The premise of The Shackles You Cannot See is to explore the blurred lines between Fate vs. Free Will in the Modern World. As a futuristic dystopian narrative, it stands as a warning of the consequences of technological advances, to make people question their actions in their daily life, as well as question their rights to psychological and physical freedom.

results.title: The Professor
results.brief_description: A Special Mention in the Middle Live Action category. Set in the 1900’s, there has been a series of unsolved murders. Two professors have been put on the case. Unfortunately for one he doesn’t know who his partner is until it’s too late.

results.title: Stories of Rippon Lea Estate
results.brief_description:
Melbourne’s historic Rippon Lea Estate is one of the fabulous locations used in the popular ‘Miss Fisher’ television series. It has also been the venue for an exhibition of the costumes from the series.
Here, staff of the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), who manage the property, talk about its history, its use as a filming location, and the relationship between the producers of the series, the National Trust, and the enthusiastic audiences for the series who have also visited Rippon Lea and the exhibition.

results.title: Stories of Labassa
results.brief_description: The historic mansion ‘Labassa’ in Melbourne has seen many occupants and much activity in its more than 150 years of existence. Bronwyn Worrall, who manages the property for the community heritage organisation, the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), discusses the building’s history as a family residence, a home for ‘hippies’ in the 1970s and its use as a location for a number of films.

results.title: Project Vena Cava [game trailer]
results.brief_description: ‘Project Vena Cava’ is an ambitious atmospheric first-person shooter with dark cinematic elements. Its storyline is science fiction themed and is delivered primarily through written documents found throughout the game, as well as a voiceover that accompanies the player throughout. It is similar in style to other sci-fi first-person shooters such as ‘Halo’, ‘Metroid Prime’ and ‘Portal’.

results.title: Sky's Adventure [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Sky’s Adventure’ is about a girl Sky and a mean girl Britney. Britney was never nice to anyone but she has to reflect on that when Sky says something to her. Will Britney change after reflecting on what she’s done or keep doing it?

results.title: Rippled
results.creator_credit: Darcy Prendergast, All India Radio and Oh Yeah Wow Pty Ltd
results.brief_description:
‘Rippled’ features a range of animation techniques - including light painting - to evoke a dystopian nighttime urban landscape of eerie beauty being explored by a creature of ambiguous identity.
Animators: Josh Thomas, Michael Greaney, Josh OKeefe, Donna Yeatman, Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury, Andrew Onorato
Music: Martin Kennedy (All India Radio)

results.title: Pifuskin
results.brief_description: Sometimes a man just has to scratch. This short animation explores notions of iritation of skin, of perception of self, of blood and bodily function.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Leo Baker
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Celebrated animator Leo Baker discusses working with Australian band ‘Children Collide’ to create a hybrid live-action and animation video for their song ‘Praying for Sunshine’. Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.
results.description: Celebrated animator Leo Baker discusses working with Australian band ‘Children Collide’ to create a hybrid live-action and animation video for their song ‘Praying for Sunshine’. Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Gotye and his Collaborators
results.creator_credit: Gotye, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Multi award-winning musician, songwriter and producer Gotye is no stranger to collaboration. His music videos are a testament to this, utilising the talents of diverse directors, artists and animators. Often involving a range of complex animation and filmmaking techniques, visual worlds are created floating seamlessly against his music.
Natasha Pincus, Andrew Goldsmith, and directors of Rubber House animation studio Ivan Dixon and Greg Sharp disscus a selection of Gotye’s most renowned videos. These include ‘Easy Way Out’, ‘Seven Hours With A Back Seat Driver’, ‘State Of The Art’ and the international chart-topping ‘Somebody That I Used To Know’.
Hosted by film and music critic Megan Spencer, this event provided a fascinating insight into the collaborative journey, from initial concept and creative development, through to final clip production.
